bibl.title: Letter from Samuel Taylor Darling to Henry Rose Carter, December 22, 1924

div1.p: Darling discusses pneumonia in South Africa and its transmission. He mentions the recent malaria conference and the paper that he presented.

December 22 - 1924.

Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I was very glad to get your letter this morning
and the Xmas greetings for Mrs. Darling, the children and myself,
and to learn that you are so well and as keenly interested as
ever in epidemiology of pneumonia and malaria.

With regard to pneumonia on the Rand I performed
a number of autopsies while I was there and found that the lesions
were those of straight lobar pneumonia or empyema and meningitis
with suppurative involvement of the accessory nasal sinuses and of
the mastoid cells exactly what I found among the recently arrived
West Indian negroes in Panama during the epidemic of pneumococcus
infection there beginning in 1905. From the circumstance of the
lesions and the involvement of the accessory sinuses and mastoid
cells I assumed that there was first an infectious respiratory
condition in the Rand just like what we had in Panama, besides
in the barracks and in the mines there was a great deal of sputum
in evidence.

Maynard's study of the incidence of pneumococcus
infection in the mines showed that the disease broke out among
recently arrived Kaffirs before they had actually gone to work
underground. Noble and I investigated the recruiting of these
Kaffirs and found that healthy recruits were mixed with unhealthy
and diseased carriers repatriates on their way back to the tracks after working and becoming infected on the mines at a compound at Rosnagarcia. The men at
night indulged in tribal dances. Both recruits and carrier
repatriates danced together in one compound and a couple of thousand
or more overheated men drank water from the two or three only
available water taps by placing the tap in their mouths. On the
mines the black miner drank tea from the bottle recently used by
Dr. Carter
Dec. 22-1924
2
the white miner who had sent his boy to “up the drive” with a tea
bottle to be filled with water. At the shaft the Kaffir boys
filled the bottle with water and drank from the water tap by placing
it in their mouths. It was easy to see how the Kaffirs picked
up pneumococci from the white miners. It was easy to see how the
recruits in turn picked up pneumococci as well as meningococci and
tubercle bacilli from the repatriates in the detention compound.

The Kaffirs did not at first suffer from pneumococcus infections in
their kraals. They acquired them directly and indirectly from the
white miner on the Rand. In the small commensal units,-barracks
holding 10 or 12 men, the death rates were low. In the large ventilated
barracks holding 60 men the rates were high for when infectious material
entered the larger barracks there were a greater numbers of men to become
infected.

At this stage of the investigation General Gorgas expressed the
opinion that pneumonia rates began to improve in Panama after the men
were scattered or permitted to live in cabins in the bush. This was
entirely new to me. I had no data to confirm it and several years later
in Panama Colonel Mason looked up the facts and told me that they did
not bear out General Gorgas' contention. I have always believed that
the epidemic wore itself out on the Isthmus because of lack of suscepti-
ble new material. General Gorgas always maintained that scattering
in Panama did the work. I recall very well the circumstances of our
investigation and report of pneumonia on the Isthmus. As a matter of
fact you did practically all of it and I merely contributed the
pathological and bacteriological end. General Gorgas recommended
in South Africa that the mine authorities place their Kaffirs in small
barracks, but the mine authorities have been unable to do this because
it would reduce the returns to the stockholders, and the mines, with
a certain few exceptions, will not live long enough in a productive
way to warrant such a change.

The conveyance in the Rand was a conveyance of pneumococci as
I have described. These were derived in the first instance from the
white man with the production of an infection of the respiratory passages
including the accessory sinuses and mastoid cells, and involving the
meninges, pleura, lungs and other organs, sometimes primarily and
sometimes secondarily.

I regret that I could not attend the Congress at Kingston. The
summer's work at the Station here required my presence to study the
problems and to give some instruction in malariology. About 55 persons
have visited the Station the past year. Most of them stayed here for
study.

In my discussion at the meeting at New Orleans on “The Relative
Importance in Transmitting Malaria of A. quadrimaculatus, A. punctipennis
and A. crucians” I referred to your paper on “The Effect of A. punctipennis
on the Natural Conveyance of Malaria Fever” Public Health Report, April, 1918
reprint No. 464, and I quoted your remark that “to spend a dollar on
sanitation and get less that 100 cents benefit is not only bad business
but bad sanitation”, and I then argued in favor of differentiating species
and breeding places, determining the specific nature of the problem
instead of attempting to use general measures,-in other words, species
control or species sanitation. I know it will be difficult to get the
engineers and the ordinary health officer to apply species control but our
two years work here has shown that it is possible and I hope that the
future will prove that it is practicable.

I shall be glad to read the biographical account of General
Gorgas. Mrs. Darling will send it to me. I have always been curious
to know what immediately led to the mosquito control operations in
Havana. Was it on xx General Gorgas' own initiative or did it come
from another person. I have heard that General Leonard Wood was the one
who initiated the movement.

I hope to have an opportunity of meeting you either in February
or May of next year.
With best wishes for yourself and Miss Laura,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, S. T. Darling,
Leesburg, Ga. STD:H
